text: Like I said I'm going to talk about how your containers aren't alone demystifying container isolation I'm Marina I'm from Adara a company that makes a hard and run time in the container isolation space Let's get into it This looks like there's a lot of people walking in right now so I'll slow roll the intro so they can all get in What is a container Hopefully you've heard of these if you're here at KCD today In case you haven't a container is a unit that packages up code and everything that's needed to run code including your libraries dependencies and configurations It lets your code run reliably in any environment It solves the it runs on my machine problem People use containers because they're lightweight they have fast startup times and they give you access to this whole environment of tools that have been built for this container ecosystem Another answer to this question what is a container translating that previous one to a little bit more Kubernetes terminology we have nodes that run on a kernel pods that have containers in them that run inside those There's of course a lot of other pieces of the ecosystem here like the control plane the kubelet etc but we're not going to talk about those today so they're not pictures To keep asking this question and to tie it back to the topic of today what containers really are is operating system virtualization They came out of Linux containers which used some advanced features of the Linux kernel to create virtualization at this operating system level instead of virtual machines which are virtualization below the operating system level Docker actually initially relied on Linux containers before they eventually developed libcontainer which is now part of Ren C That's the history of how these containers have come to be what we see them as today The key technologies that made these initial containers and the containers we use today possible are namespaces and cgroups Let's start there What are namespaces and cgroups Namespaces create distinct contexts within the kernel for each container so they each see a different set of There are lots of different types of namespaces for specific resources including process IDs networking etc but they all do the same thing of creating distinct contexts Cgroups are also a Linux kernel feature that puts limits on the usage of resources such as CPUs or memory In the context of containers these can prevent things like a noisy neighbor attack where one container accesses the whole CPU and the other containers don't get access to any of it at all This might sound like some isolation right We're separating our resources we're separating different things with these namespaces and cgroups Why are we still talking about container isolation That sounds like isolation right The main thing is that even though you have these namespaces and cgroups which are features of the Linux kernel there's still the whole rest of the shared kernel with lots of functionality that's either not covered by namespaces and cgroups or is below them in the stack This means that things like networking things like memory are shared between containers Also things like system configurations are often viewable from the A fun thing that you can do actually I should probably finish the is just open up a Docker container an unprivileged container the default configs in Docker and just see what you can see of the file system of your host machine I think you'll be surprised at how many processes and services and stuff that you can still see from inside the For example an attacker could see a vulnerable kernel version or a misconfiguration of your Docker settings that could lead to them being able to do an attack or they could just interfere with the system's There are a lot of things that are actually file descriptors under the hood in Linux that you can actually write to and that messes up your whole system entropy This doesn't even take into account bugs in the technologies of namespaces C groups or the kernel itself that can let a user in a container do even more Isolation is especially important when we have multi tenancy Folks often run containers in multi tenant environments meaning containers from multiple different organizations or different users of the same organization are sharing the same infrastructure This is great for resource efficiency This means that you can share the resources that you're actually using and other tenants pay for the rest of the machine This makes it pretty common in Unfortunately this exposes you to some of these hidden assumptions about the isolation of Containers include everything they need to run an but they're running this application inside the same kernel as other containers They're similar to processes inside the This means that if other mechanisms are not in containers might be able to view the host system itself That's an example of an attack there What we need is some mechanism in to create this isolation To illustrate why we need container isolation even more in case you're not convinced yet here are a few container escape vulnerabilities from the past year or so that led to This seems to not be displaying properly Oh well That's weird Let's see if the next slide is  Anyway it's not important what they are It's different attacks in this space that can lead to breaking these assumptions around container isolation That's the main point there The point is that isolation is hard and we want to prevent these types of attacks on our system by creating a better layer of There are a lot of different technologies that provide isolation These three general categories vaguely align with the technology stack Then we're going to talk about some open source technologies in each of these categories so you can get a sense of how they all fit together First we have application and service isolation which separate workloads and APIs at that user space level Things like namespaces and cgroups are the foundational beginning also fit into this Runtime isolation enforces boundaries in the compute environment itself and hardware and physical isolation creates physical boundaries between workloads things like error gaps confidential computing Of course when deploying an isolation probably isn't the only thing or maybe not even the first thing that you think about when doing that I think it's important to look at these two especially as we go through these technologies so we can think of why you might use one over the other The level of that's the one we talked about and then technologies introduce hardware requirements compatibility with your existing workloads and tooling and all of these different things can be important depending on your exact application how sensitive is it how performant does it need to be where does it need to run all that kind of stuff So let's get specific First we'll go into more technologies in the application and service isolation space That was a little bit of a lag Let's talk about the system calls a container can make This limits the attack surface within the container itself because there's less system calls that the container can access which gives it less ways to try and break out of that Linux capabilities divide superuser privileges into distinct units This is great if you want to give a container some privileges but you don't want to just have a privileged container You can give it just the ones that defines access control for the applications and files inside the with policies set for those So all these technologies these application and service isolation ones as well as namespaces and cgroups they work inside the Linux kernel They're features of the kernel that you can add more isolation to your create more boxes inside the kernel that separate different pieces of from your container Everything in this category because it's working on top of the there's still a shared kernel This is just putting little layers between it and the kernel but it's not actually eliminating that fundamental sharing of it If you want to do that I think we're going to talk next about runtime isolation This goes a level deeper in isolation of what happens if we actually eliminate that shared kernel altogether It's called a userspace application kernel This is kind of cool because it provides the same separate kernel for each container but it does it in userspace which means that there's no hardware compatibility issues or anything like that that you have to deal with It's able to prevent a lot of the known attacks on isolation while doing so in userspace That's pretty cool To talk about the rest we're going to use these with containers I think a lot of people think that they're incompatible technologies so we're going to explain how we're going to make them work together This is a traditional virtual machine that I'll talk about first as a separate operating system kernel for each workload To achieve this there's the hardware and you have a hypervisor that runs on the and the VM mediates all access to the CPU memory and everything below it The guest operating systems are not able to access those resources below it without going through that layer This provides a really clean isolation boundary You can see how as opposed to where you have this shared kernel it creates a clean separation of the resources Virtual machines especially traditional ones can run an entire operating system just to run a single workload What folks have done is they've designed what are called micro VMs to get a lot of the isolation benefits of virtual machines with a little bit less overhead Same kind of general design here we have an additional container runtime layer to make this container compatible The other thing here that's a little bit different is there's also a lot of tricks you can do if you control the whole stack like having read only shared memory for the kernel itself You do have a separate kernel for each one but there's pieces of the kernel that are the same that can actually just be in memory once so you're not duplicating things That's in a read only section of memory so it can't actually be You have to look at these different layers and how they all kind of fit together First at the bottom we have the hypervisor The two probably most common ones open source ones are Xen and KVM KVM is a type 2 or hosted hypervisor that acts as a module in the Linux kernel that enables the use of hardware virtualization features on CPUs In the cloud this use virtualization features to your non bare metal instance which is not super common in the kind of popular clouds or it can be expensive Xen is a standalone or type 1 hypervisor that supports both hardware virtualization in what's called TVH mode or paravirtualization which means it can run on any CPU or any cloud environment without actually that bare metal access So that can be nice if you're trying to do this in the cloud Going up the stack we have the virtual machine manager Some folks also refer to this as the hypervisor but they always need to run on top of the other ones so I like to separate them The first one I'll talk about here is Firecracker which is a VMM that powers AWS Lambda and Fargate It's I think most famous for having really fast boot times It's kind of their claim to fame and it kind of creates a small attack surface at this VMM layer That runs on top of KVM and then you need some kind of container runtime on top of it to then run your Cloud Hypervisor is another VMM optimized for cloud native workloads backed by Intel also runs on KVM Next we have Kata containers This is the container runtime so now you have to pick one of those other VMMs There's also lots I don't have time to cover today so those are all great too On top of those you run Kata containers and then this is a lightweight container runtime that lets you run OCI compliant containers so the containers you have today inside a microVM And then yeah you run on top of those other layers Another system this one's actually more of an end to end than it is one of the layers is Apple's Containerization Framework This also uses a microVM architecture It's specifically optimized for Apple Silicon which you know them having control of the entire stack gave them some cool opportunities to do some optimizations here And this gives you strong isolation even in development environments So if you're developing in this Apple Container Framework you kind of get this kind of isolation even on your dev machine which is really great for running untrusted workloads locally so you're looking at some vulnerabilities and want to try to see what they do or you're doing early testing of an application where you're not really sure what it's going to do You can still put it in a super isolated environment here Another one that's a little bit different is a unikernel which is kind of similar to microVM but a bit more lightweight at the expense of compatibility with your existing containers But it's much more lightweight which is very cool What it does is it compiles your application with a microkernel to create what I like to think of as a single application mini kernel So you run this kind of mini operating system thing with your application on top of the hypervisor and VMM et And this is super  strong isolation again but with a lot less    of the overhead In some cases this can even be faster than traditional containers because you have so much less overhead there But there's of course limitations in terms of  If you have to rebuild your application you have to then rebuild the kernel which is a little bit inefficient So that can be pretty tricky And also it's not necessarily compatible with every environment you want to run it in But for especially things like IoT kind of edge devices type stuff this can be a really lightweight option for isolation So that's the So in summary runtime technologies except GeoVisor which I also kind of categorize here have a separate kernel and GeoVisor has a separate user space kernel so a similar idea per container which provides kind of a strong security boundary That isolation boundary is kind of like in a really strong place around the and without relying on those kind of kernel mechanisms Of course you should probably still use those kernel mechanisms right There's no need to limit yourself in terms of what you can do to secure your applications But some of these technologies are come with performance or security tradeoffs or have hardware requirements that you need to start thinking about in order to get them deployed And so that's kind of the tradeoff you have to make in figuring out if this is the right decision But if you need more isolation I think looking into these technologies is probably worth it Finally we have hardware and physical isolation So this is for when you really want to make sure that stuff is not going to be able to with each other The first method I think the first one that probably comes to mind for folks is an air duct So you've got a completely separate machine generally even completely separate from the internet right So you have it running in a place where stuff really can't interfere with it And anything coming from the internet has to kind of pass through some sort of interface to get there Great for obviously because not only do you have no shared kernel there's no shared hardware there's no internet like great isolation And this is great for kind of edge highly secure environment type stuff but it can be kind of expensive or impractical because you actually have you know not only separate hardware you have to deal with this interface layer and all of that But of course very isolated And we also have confidential computing So the idea with confidential computing is you have what's called a execution environment or TEE which is a piece of hardware that kind of runs alongside your CPU and you can run your container inside the TEE This is generally done alongside a microkernel setup so you have the kind of the kernel run inside the TEE so it has everything it needs to run And  And examples of this for the ecosystem include constellation and confidential containers which are both open source kind of CNCF projects that work in this space kind of providing this Again very strong isolation because it has this hardware component that your container is running on It's like you know separate than it running on the CPU You have things like encrypted memory kind of encrypted data in use but you do need you know access to this hardware chip and they have somewhat limited number of containers you can run per chip So this can be a little bit tricky to do Probably best for like when you really need like an even stronger isolation So here's a quick summary of the isolation mechanisms we've discussed We have a bunch in the application and service isolation Those are the ones that are running kind of at the top of the stack in this Linux kernel We have runtime isolation What if we separate the kernels from each other And then we have hardware and physical isolation which is you know we don't even want the same hardware between our different things We want it like really in its own space And that's just what I wanted to talk about there So just a quick summary And then I'm going to move on really quickly to because it's 2025 so here we are We're going to talk about AI Specifically what I mean is we're going to talk about GPUs right And I think the AI workloads have meant that people have been seeing a huge increase in the use of GPUs by container workloads especially for inference which I think is more relevant here I think folks doing training often have access to their own machines their own GPUs but also for like if you're running an application that just has some AI usage you're probably using inference and inference runs better on GPUs So why are we talking about isolation in GPUs GPUs are expensive I'm sure folks are aware of that And so we want to optimize the uses of our GPU and make sure we can use you know every second of that GPU time that we can So we want to make sure that all of our different containers running on our system can share this GPU Unfortunately GPUs weren't really designed for  that They weren't really designed for this right Things like memory is not always cleared between different processes running on the GPU They're really designed for speed right That's the whole point of a And I think some of these multi tendency on GPUs is a little bit new and evolving So I'll talk about some of the stuff that exists today and we can kind of imagine a future where we can do this maybe more efficiently too So here's a bunch of strategies for sharing GPU among multiple containers kind of roughly in order of where they fit in the stack So at the top we have GPU timesharing This includes things like NVIDIA vGPU or Intel's GVTG sorry which allows for things like context switching between containers I don't say that aloud that often sorry And this provides software level isolation But it doesn't always do things like clearing memory between applications which can be a big problem which means that like if you have you know multi tenancy you have two different applications that don't know about each other one of them can be able to read the memory left over in the  GPU from the previous one And we've actually seen attacks on GPUs for even just in things like browser rendering where one browser tab might be able to see what was rendered in another browser tab because they run on the same GPU So this is kind of a tricky thing here Another thing is that vGPU specifically actually requires that you buy a license per GPU that you use it on which can be a little bit prohibitively expensive if you're doing like an at scale cloud application So    Next on the stack we have GPU partitioning which includes things like NVIDIA multi instance GPU or MIG and AMD's MX GPU So what both of these do is they kind of split the into slices at the hardware level So you can provide like a slice of the GPU to one container a slice to another container et cetera And then finally PCI pass through passes an entire GPU to a VM This is the best for isolation because you don't have to worry about the GPU partitioning because you don't  have to worry about doing the partitioning properly but you don't have to worry about bugs in that So it works for VMs of You have to give direct access But of course you're not really splitting time on your GPU You're just kind of giving the GPU to this thing clearing the GPU out giving the whole GPU to this thing which again provides you better isolation but maybe you know not as much efficiency So in summary yeah we have GPU timesharing which does software isolation You might have to worry about some shared memory pieces GPU partitioning PCI paths through both hardware level GPU partitioning actually splits the GPU PCI paths through passes it up to your containers kind of one at a So and I think just kind of taking a step back here from the specifics of how you actually share a GPU between your containers I think we talked about why you know why does this matter So container isolation I think is especially important when we're talking about adding GPUs to the mix Because we don't have the GPU to run as many isolation boundaries internally You know we've been seeing especially in the past year or so I think five or six different vulnerabilities in different GPUs because people are starting to try and run multi tenant applications on them And so without careful design containers with access to the might be able to read information from GPU or other GPU workloads which is especially bad if this contains sensitive data like model weights user data or other things like that that you're running on this GPU So the point here really is that you need to make sure that whatever you're doing for container isolation takes into account pieces of the hardware like the GPU and how that isolation actually applies throughout the  And isolation mechanisms from you know from earlier in the talk that work at the hardware or kernel or right below the kernel have an advantage because they can be a little bit more hardware aware Right If something is running inside the Linux kernel it has to be compatible across hardware so it can be it kind of is definitionally a little bit less aware of the kind of the full stack here And I think that this will improve over time I think that you know as you know inference has become more common as new GPUs come out it just you know it takes time to develop hardware and so this will keep getting better and hopefully we'll find you know a similar set of you know open source open standard ways of doing GPU isolation that can fit in with the whole kind of world that we have today of CPU isolation So bringing it all together containers are operating system virtualization That's what they do They use   a lot of these namespaces that you see groups to kind of create a view on the operating system but they're still kind of running like processes on your operating system Multi tenant applications require more isolation because when you know when you're having that shared kernel you have to make sure that they can't impact other containers or the operating system in ways that you don't want Container isolation strategies include things that the application and service level things running on the kernel You have runtime isolation and it takes a step below So how can we actually have a separate kernel per container and hardware and physical isolation which takes it one step even further to see you know what happens if we have separate hardware for each of our containers AI applications need both container isolation and GPU isolation and I think we should all be talking more about how we can get that GPU isolation to be easy and seamless like some of these container isolation strategies are already So thank you I think we have a couple minutes for questions because    I probably talked too fast So thank you all Applause
